trans-unit.source: Use the autoscaling application block (.NET) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Use the autoscaling application block (.NET) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Autoscaling Application for Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Autoscaling Application for Azure.

trans-unit.source: Code samples are written in C# and use the .NET API.
trans-unit.target: Code samples are written in C# and use the .NET API.

trans-unit.source: How to Use the Autoscaling Application Block
trans-unit.target: How to Use the Autoscaling Application Block

trans-unit.source: This guide will demonstrate how to perform common scenarios using the
trans-unit.target: This guide will demonstrate how to perform common scenarios using the

trans-unit.source: Autoscaling Application Block from the [Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure][].
trans-unit.target: Autoscaling Application Block from the [Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure][].

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C\
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C\

trans-unit.source: and use the .NET API.
trans-unit.target: and use the .NET API.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include **hosting the block**, **using constraint rules**, and **using reactive rules**.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include **hosting the block**, **using constraint rules**, and **using reactive rules**.

trans-unit.source: For
trans-unit.target: For

trans-unit.source: more information on the Autoscaling Application Block, see the [Next Steps](#next-steps) section.
trans-unit.target: more information on the Autoscaling Application Block, see the [Next Steps](#next-steps) section.

trans-unit.source: What is the Autoscaling Application Block?
trans-unit.target: What is the Autoscaling Application Block?

trans-unit.source: The Autoscaling Application Block can automatically scale your
trans-unit.target: The Autoscaling Application Block can automatically scale your

trans-unit.source: Azure application based on rules that you define specifically for your
trans-unit.target: Azure application based on rules that you define specifically for your

trans-unit.source: application.
trans-unit.target: application.

trans-unit.source: You can use these rules to help your Azure
trans-unit.target: You can use these rules to help your Azure

trans-unit.source: application maintain its throughput in response to changes in its
trans-unit.target: application maintain its throughput in response to changes in its

trans-unit.source: workload, while at the same time control the costs associated with
trans-unit.target: workload, while at the same time control the costs associated with

trans-unit.source: hosting your application in Azure.
trans-unit.target: hosting your application in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Along with scaling by
trans-unit.target: Along with scaling by

trans-unit.source: increasing or decreasing the number of role instances in your
trans-unit.target: increasing or decreasing the number of role instances in your

trans-unit.source: application, the block also enables you to use other scaling actions
trans-unit.target: application, the block also enables you to use other scaling actions

trans-unit.source: such as throttling certain functionality within your application or
trans-unit.target: such as throttling certain functionality within your application or

trans-unit.source: using custom-defined actions.
trans-unit.target: using custom-defined actions.

trans-unit.source: You can choose to host the block in an Azure role or in an
trans-unit.target: You can choose to host the block in an Azure role or in an

trans-unit.source: on-premises application.
trans-unit.target: on-premises application.

trans-unit.source: The Autoscaling Application Block is part of the [Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure][].
trans-unit.target: The Autoscaling Application Block is part of the [Microsoft Enterprise Library 5.0 Integration Pack for Azure][].

trans-unit.source: Concepts
trans-unit.target: Concepts

trans-unit.source: In the following diagram, the green line shows a plot of the number of
trans-unit.target: In the following diagram, the green line shows a plot of the number of

trans-unit.source: running instances of an Azure role over two days.
trans-unit.target: running instances of an Azure role over two days.

trans-unit.source: The number of
trans-unit.target: The number of

trans-unit.source: instances changes automatically over time in response to a set of
trans-unit.target: instances changes automatically over time in response to a set of

trans-unit.source: autoscaling rules.
trans-unit.target: autoscaling rules.

trans-unit.source: diagram of sample autoscaling
trans-unit.target: diagram of sample autoscaling

trans-unit.source: The block uses two types of rules to define the autoscaling behavior for
trans-unit.target: The block uses two types of rules to define the autoscaling behavior for

trans-unit.source: your application:
trans-unit.target: your application:

trans-unit.source: **Constraint Rules:** To set upper and lower bounds on the number of
trans-unit.target: **Constraint Rules:** To set upper and lower bounds on the number of

trans-unit.source: instances, for example, let's say that between 8:00 and 10:00 every
trans-unit.target: instances, for example, let's say that between 8:00 and 10:00 every

trans-unit.source: morning you want a minimum of four and a maximum of six instances,
trans-unit.target: morning you want a minimum of four and a maximum of six instances,

trans-unit.source: then you use a **constraint rule**.
trans-unit.target: then you use a **constraint rule**.

trans-unit.source: In the diagram, the red and blue
trans-unit.target: In the diagram, the red and blue

trans-unit.source: lines represent constraint rules.
trans-unit.target: lines represent constraint rules.

trans-unit.source: For example, at point **A** in
trans-unit.target: For example, at point **A** in

trans-unit.source: the diagram, the minimum number of role instances rises from two to
trans-unit.target: the diagram, the minimum number of role instances rises from two to

trans-unit.source: four, in order to accommodate the anticipated increase in the
trans-unit.target: four, in order to accommodate the anticipated increase in the

trans-unit.source: application's workload at this time.
trans-unit.target: application's workload at this time.

trans-unit.source: At point **B** in the diagram,
trans-unit.target: At point **B** in the diagram,

trans-unit.source: the number of role instances is prevented from climbing above five
trans-unit.target: the number of role instances is prevented from climbing above five

trans-unit.source: in order to control the running costs of the application.
trans-unit.target: in order to control the running costs of the application.

trans-unit.source: **Reactive Rules:** To enable the number of role instances to change
trans-unit.target: **Reactive Rules:** To enable the number of role instances to change

trans-unit.source: in response to unpredictable changes in demand, you use **reactive rules**.
trans-unit.target: in response to unpredictable changes in demand, you use **reactive rules**.

trans-unit.source: At point **C** in the diagram, the block automatically
trans-unit.target: At point **C** in the diagram, the block automatically

trans-unit.source: reduces the number of role instances, from four to three, in
trans-unit.target: reduces the number of role instances, from four to three, in

trans-unit.source: response to a reduction in workload.
trans-unit.target: response to a reduction in workload.

trans-unit.source: At point **D**, the block
trans-unit.target: At point **D**, the block

trans-unit.source: detects an increase in workload and automatically increases the
trans-unit.target: detects an increase in workload and automatically increases the

trans-unit.source: number of running role instances from three to four.
trans-unit.target: number of running role instances from three to four.

trans-unit.source: The block stores its configuration settings in two stores:
trans-unit.target: The block stores its configuration settings in two stores:

trans-unit.source: **Rules Store:** The Rules Store holds your business configuration;
trans-unit.target: **Rules Store:** The Rules Store holds your business configuration;

trans-unit.source: a list of all the autoscaling rules that you have defined for your
trans-unit.target: a list of all the autoscaling rules that you have defined for your

trans-unit.source: Azure application.
trans-unit.target: Azure application.

trans-unit.source: This store is typically an XML file that
trans-unit.target: This store is typically an XML file that

trans-unit.source: is located where the Autoscaling Application Block can read it, for
trans-unit.target: is located where the Autoscaling Application Block can read it, for

trans-unit.source: example in Azure blob storage or in a local file.
trans-unit.target: example in Azure blob storage or in a local file.

trans-unit.source: **Service Information Store:** The Service Information Store stores
trans-unit.target: **Service Information Store:** The Service Information Store stores

trans-unit.source: your operational configuration, which is the service model of your
trans-unit.target: your operational configuration, which is the service model of your

trans-unit.source: Azure application.
trans-unit.target: Azure application.

trans-unit.source: This service model includes all of the
trans-unit.target: This service model includes all of the

trans-unit.source: information about your Azure application (such as role names
trans-unit.target: information about your Azure application (such as role names

trans-unit.source: and storage account details) that the block needs to be able to
trans-unit.target: and storage account details) that the block needs to be able to

trans-unit.source: collect data points from the target Azure application and to
trans-unit.target: collect data points from the target Azure application and to

trans-unit.source: perform scaling operations.
trans-unit.target: perform scaling operations.

trans-unit.source: Collect Performance Counter Data from your Target Azure Application
trans-unit.target: Collect Performance Counter Data from your Target Azure Application

trans-unit.source: Reactive rules can use performance counter data from roles as part of
trans-unit.target: Reactive rules can use performance counter data from roles as part of

trans-unit.source: the rule definition.
trans-unit.target: the rule definition.

trans-unit.source: For example, a reactive rule may monitor the CPU
trans-unit.target: For example, a reactive rule may monitor the CPU

trans-unit.source: utilization of an Azure role to determine whether the block
trans-unit.target: utilization of an Azure role to determine whether the block

trans-unit.source: should initiate a scaling operation.
trans-unit.target: should initiate a scaling operation.

trans-unit.source: The block reads performance counter
trans-unit.target: The block reads performance counter

trans-unit.source: data from the Azure Diagnostics table named
trans-unit.target: data from the Azure Diagnostics table named

trans-unit.source: **WADPerformanceCountersTable** in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: **WADPerformanceCountersTable** in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: By default, Azure does not write performance counter data to the
trans-unit.target: By default, Azure does not write performance counter data to the

trans-unit.source: Azure Diagnostics table in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: Azure Diagnostics table in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you

trans-unit.source: should modify the roles from which you need to collect performance
trans-unit.target: should modify the roles from which you need to collect performance

trans-unit.source: counter data to save this data.
trans-unit.target: counter data to save this data.

trans-unit.source: For details about how to enable
trans-unit.target: For details about how to enable

trans-unit.source: performance counters in your application, see [Using performance counters in Azure][].
trans-unit.target: performance counters in your application, see [Using performance counters in Azure][].

trans-unit.source: Set up a Host Application for the Autoscaling Application Block
trans-unit.target: Set up a Host Application for the Autoscaling Application Block

trans-unit.source: You can host the Autoscaling Application Block either in an Azure
trans-unit.target: You can host the Autoscaling Application Block either in an Azure

trans-unit.source: role or in an on-premises application.
trans-unit.target: role or in an on-premises application.

trans-unit.source: The Autoscaling Application Block
trans-unit.target: The Autoscaling Application Block

trans-unit.source: is typically hosted in a separate application from the target
trans-unit.target: is typically hosted in a separate application from the target

trans-unit.source: application that you want to scale automatically.
trans-unit.target: application that you want to scale automatically.

trans-unit.source: This section provides
trans-unit.target: This section provides

trans-unit.source: guidelines about how to configure your host application.
trans-unit.target: guidelines about how to configure your host application.

trans-unit.source: In this example there are three autoscaling rules (one **constraint rule** and two **reactive rules**) that operate on a target named
trans-unit.target: In this example there are three autoscaling rules (one **constraint rule** and two **reactive rules**) that operate on a target named

trans-unit.source: **AutoscalingApplicationRole** that is the alias of a role defined in
trans-unit.target: **AutoscalingApplicationRole** that is the alias of a role defined in

trans-unit.source: the **service model**:
trans-unit.target: the **service model**:

trans-unit.source: The constraint rule is always active and sets the minimum number of
trans-unit.target: The constraint rule is always active and sets the minimum number of

trans-unit.source: role instances to two and the maximum number of role instances to
trans-unit.target: role instances to two and the maximum number of role instances to

trans-unit.source: six.
trans-unit.target: six.

trans-unit.source: Both reactive rules use an **operand** named
trans-unit.target: Both reactive rules use an **operand** named

trans-unit.source: **WebRoleA\_CPU\_Avg\_5m** that calculates the average CPU usage
trans-unit.target: **WebRoleA\_CPU\_Avg\_5m** that calculates the average CPU usage

trans-unit.source: over the last five minutes for an Azure role named
trans-unit.target: over the last five minutes for an Azure role named

trans-unit.source: AutoscalingApplicationRole.
trans-unit.target: AutoscalingApplicationRole.

trans-unit.target: This role is defined in the

trans-unit.source: **service model**.
trans-unit.target: **service model**.

trans-unit.source: The reactive rule named **ScaleUpOnHighUtilization** increments the
trans-unit.target: The reactive rule named **ScaleUpOnHighUtilization** increments the

trans-unit.source: instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU
trans-unit.target: instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU

trans-unit.source: utilization over the last five minutes has been greater than or
trans-unit.target: utilization over the last five minutes has been greater than or

trans-unit.source: equal to 60%.
trans-unit.target: equal to 60%.

trans-unit.source: The reactive rule named **ScaleDownOnLowUtilization** decrements the
trans-unit.target: The reactive rule named **ScaleDownOnLowUtilization** decrements the

trans-unit.source: instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU
trans-unit.target: instance count of the target role by one if the average CPU

trans-unit.source: utilization over the last five minutes has been less than 60%.
trans-unit.target: utilization over the last five minutes has been less than 60%.

trans-unit.source: How To: Configure the Autoscaling Application Block
trans-unit.target: How To: Configure the Autoscaling Application Block

trans-unit.source: After you have defined your service model and autoscaling rules, you
trans-unit.target: After you have defined your service model and autoscaling rules, you

trans-unit.source: must configure the Autoscaling Application Block to use them.
trans-unit.target: must configure the Autoscaling Application Block to use them.

trans-unit.source: This
trans-unit.target: This

trans-unit.source: operational configuration information is stored in the application
trans-unit.target: operational configuration information is stored in the application

trans-unit.source: configuration file.
trans-unit.target: configuration file.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Autoscaling Application Block expects the autoscaling
trans-unit.target: By default, the Autoscaling Application Block expects the autoscaling

trans-unit.source: rules and service model to be stored in Azure blobs.
trans-unit.target: rules and service model to be stored in Azure blobs.

trans-unit.source: In this
trans-unit.target: In this

trans-unit.source: example, you will configure the block to load them from the local file
trans-unit.target: example, you will configure the block to load them from the local file

trans-unit.target: system.

trans-unit.source: Configure the Autoscaling Application Block in the host application
trans-unit.target: Configure the Autoscaling Application Block in the host application

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the **App.config** file in Solution Explorer and then
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the **App.config** file in Solution Explorer and then

trans-unit.source: click **Edit Configuration File**.
trans-unit.target: click **Edit Configuration File**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Blocks** menu, click **Add Autoscaling Settings**:
